charge.translation[0].definitions[0].def: the amount of money you have to pay for goods or services
charge.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: Guided tours are provided at no charge.
Your order will be sent free of charge (=with no cost).
There is a charge for the use of the swimming pool.
charge.translation[0].definitions[1].def: the position of having control or responsibility for a group of people or an activity
charge.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: Stern put Travis in charge of (=gave him control of) the research team.
Owens came in and took charge of (=took control of) the situation.
A commander in each county was to have charge of the local militia.
He asked to speak to the person in charge.
the officer in charge of the investigation
charge.translation[0].definitions[2].def: if someone or something is in your charge, you are responsible for looking after them
charge.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: teachers that do their best for the children in their charge
The files were left in your charge.
charge.translation[0].definitions[3].def: someone that you are responsible for looking after
charge.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: Sarah bought some chocolate for her three young charges.
charge.translation[0].definitions[4].def: an official statement by the police that someone may be guilty of a crime
charge.translation[0].definitions[4].exa: He was found guilty of all six charges against him.
Higgins is facing a charge of armed robbery.
The following morning, he was arrested on a charge of burglary.
charge.translation[0].definitions[5].def: a written or spoken statement blaming someone for doing something bad or illegal
charge.translation[0].definitions[5].exa: Wallace denied charges that he had lied to investigators.
The speech laid him open to charges of political bias.
lay/leave yourself open to a charge of something
the charge that tobacco companies target young people with their ads
a charge of racial discrimination against the company
charge.translation[0].definitions[6].def: an attack in which soldiers or animals move towards someone or something very quickly
charge.translation[0].definitions[7].def: electricity that is put into a piece of electrical equipment such as a battery
charge.translation[0].definitions[7].exa: Leave the battery on charge all night.
charge.translation[0].definitions[8].def: an explosive put into something such as a bomb or gun
charge.translation[0].definitions[9].exa: Cases of child abuse have a strong emotional charge.
charge.translation[0].definitions[10].ex: The old servant fulfilled his master’s charge to care for the children.
charge.translation[0].note_box[0].headin: – Meaning 1: the amount of money you have to pay for goods or services
charge.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: For a small charge guests can use the hotel sauna.
Breakfast may be served in your bedroom at no extra charge.
There’s a fixed charge for having a dental check.
You can use the tennis courts for a nominal charge.
There’s a minimum charge of £10 per person in the Terrace restaurant.
The restaurant’s prices include a 10% service charge.
The electrician said there is a £40 call-out charge.
If you change your flight booking, you may have to pay a cancellation charge.
How much is the store’s delivery charge?
You will have to pay bank charges if your account is overdrawn.
There will be a small charge to pay.
We make no charge for this service.
The government introduced a charge for water.
I’ve asked the bank to waive the charge this time.
charge.translation[0].note_box[1].headin: – Meaning 4: an official statement by the police that someone may be guilty of a crime
charge.translation[0].note_box[1].sectio: ADJECTIVES/NOUN + charge
a murder/burglary/drugs etc charge
He appeared in court on fraud charges.
Robins was in jail awaiting trial on drugs charges.
criminal charges
The investigation resulted in criminal charges against three police officers.
a serious charge
Drinking and driving is a very serious charge.
a felony charge
He pleaded not guilty to a felony charge of cocaine possession.
press/bring charges
Sometimes the victim of an assault does not want to press charges.
face charges
A farmer is facing charges of cruelty and neglect.
deny/admit a charge
All three men denied the charge of manslaughter.
plead guilty to a charge
The youth pleaded guilty to a charge of arson.
drop the charges
The prosecution dropped the charges in 2005.
dismiss the charges
If there is insufficient evidence, the court will dismiss the charges.
be released without charge
She had been arrested twice and released without charge.
be convicted of/on a charge
McCorley was convicted on a charge of assault.
be acquitted of/on a charge
Both men were acquitted of all charges.
charge.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to ask someone for a particular amount of money for something you are selling
charge.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: The restaurant charged us £40 for the wine.
The gallery charges an entrance fee.
Calls will be charged at 44p per minute.
We won’t charge for delivery if you pay now.
charge.translation[1].definitions[1].def: to record the cost of something on someone’s account, so that they can pay for it later
charge.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: Wilson charged the drinks to his room.
Use a courier and charge it to the department.
charge.translation[1].definitions[2].def: to pay for something with a credit card
charge.translation[1].definitions[2].exa: ‘How would you like to pay?’ ‘I’ll charge it.’
I charged the shoes on Visa.
charge.translation[1].definitions[3].def: to state officially that someone may be guilty of a crime
charge.translation[1].definitions[3].exa: Gibbons has been charged with murder.
charge.translation[1].definitions[4].def: to say publicly that you think someone has done something wrong
charge.translation[1].definitions[4].exa: Demonstrators have charged that the police used excessive force against them.
charge.translation[1].definitions[5].def: to deliberately run or walk somewhere quickly
charge.translation[1].definitions[5].exa: The boys charged noisily into the water.
charge.translation[1].definitions[6].def: to deliberately rush quickly towards someone or something in order to attack them
charge.translation[1].definitions[6].exa: Then, with a final effort, our men charged the enemy for the last time.
The bear charged towards her at full speed.
charge.translation[1].definitions[7].def: if a battery charges, or if you charge it, it takes in and stores electricity
charge.translation[1].definitions[7].exa: The shaver can be charged up.
charge.translation[1].definitions[8].def: to order someone to do something or make them responsible for it
charge.translation[1].definitions[8].exa: The commission is charged with investigating war crimes.
charge.translation[2].definitions[0].def: an amount of money paid for services or goods
charge.translation[2].definitions[0].exa: Vodafone is cutting its call charges by 15%.
You can search the database free of charge.
Politicians are opposing higher charges for electricity.
charge.translation[2].definitions[1].def: money charged by a bank for services such as paying cheques, sending out bank statements etc
charge.translation[2].definitions[1].exa: concern at the level of bank charges charged by some of the High Street banks
charge.translation[2].definitions[2].def: a legal right to an asset belonging to another person if a particular event happens, for example if they do not repay a loan with which they bought the asset
charge.translation[2].definitions[2].exa: Fund the purchase of the house by a loan, with the lender holding a charge on the property as security.
charge.translation[2].definitions[3].def: a cost, especially one that is not paid regularly
charge.translation[2].definitions[3].exa: The company’s net loss for the period will also include a restructuring charge of $12 million.
Denver said it will take a charge (=pay a cost) of about $590 million for the write-off of certain assets.
charge.translation[2].definitions[4].def: to be the person who manages a group of people, an organization, or an activity
charge.translation[2].definitions[4].exa: Under the new plan, each board member will be in charge of one product area.
He was put in charge of GM’s worldwide truck operations.
charge.translation[2].definitions[5].def: to take control of a group of people, an organization, or an activity
charge.translation[2].definitions[5].exa: After a brief power struggle, she took charge of the family firm.
charge.translation[2].definitions[6].def: an official statement saying that someone has done something against the law
charge.translation[2].definitions[6].exa: He was arrested on charges of bribery.
The charges against him are expected to cover fraud, forgery and fraudulent bankruptcy.
charge.translation[3].definitions[0].def: to ask someone to pay a particular amount of money for something
charge.translation[3].definitions[0].exa: She was charged $995 for a belt that really only cost $195.
The prices that producers charged for food fell by 0.8% in July.
charge.translation[3].definitions[1].def: to record the cost of something on someone’s account so they can pay for it later
charge.translation[3].definitions[1].exa: Charge the room to the company’s account.
charge.translation[3].definitions[2].def: to pay for something with a CREDIT CARD
charge.translation[3].definitions[2].exa: I charged the shoes on my Visa card.
charge.translation[3].definitions[3].def: to state officially that someone has done something against the law
